clinician: Hello Mei Lin, thank you for coming in today. I’d like to start by understanding how you’ve been feeling lately and what has brought you here. Can you tell me a bit about what’s been going on for you recently?
patient: Hi, um, thank you for having me. Honestly, I’ve been feeling really tired all the time, even when I get enough sleep. I find it hard to concentrate in class or when I’m studying, and I feel kind of overwhelmed, like I’m just not doing enough. I also feel pretty isolated, like I don’t really have anyone to talk to about how I’m feeling. It’s been getting worse over the past few months, and I guess I just don’t know how to handle it anymore.

clinician: It sounds like you're experiencing a lot of fatigue, difficulty focusing, and feelings of isolation, and that these feelings have been intensifying over time. When you mention feeling overwhelmed and not knowing how to handle it, can you tell me more about what specific situations or thoughts tend to make you feel this way?
patient: Yeah, I think a lot of it comes from trying to keep up with my classes and work, especially since I’m always worried about falling behind or not doing well enough. I keep thinking that I have to prove myself, not just to my professors but to my family too, so they can be proud of me. Sometimes, I get these thoughts that maybe I’m not cut out for this, or that I don’t belong here, and that makes me feel even more alone. I also feel guilty because I can’t spend as much time with my family or friends, and I worry they might think I don’t care. It’s like this constant pressure that just doesn’t let up.

clinician: It sounds like you're carrying a lot of pressure to succeed academically and to meet your family's expectations, which is adding to your feelings of being overwhelmed and isolated. The thoughts about not belonging and feeling guilty about your relationships seem to be significant sources of distress. When you notice these thoughts or feelings, how do you usually respond to them? Do you have any ways of coping with these pressures?
patient: Honestly, I usually just try to push through it and keep going, even if I feel like I’m about to break. Sometimes I tell myself I just need to work harder or be more organized, but it doesn’t really help much. I don’t really talk about these feelings with anyone because I’m afraid they’ll think I’m weak or that I’m just making excuses. I guess I just try to ignore it and hope it goes away, but it doesn’t seem to work. It’s like I’m stuck in this cycle I can’t get out of.

clinician:
It sounds like you're pushing yourself very hard and trying to handle everything on your own, which can be exhausting and might make the feelings of being stuck even worse. Not sharing these feelings with others because of fear of judgment is understandable, but it also seems to be contributing to your sense of isolation. 

Given what you've shared, I’d like to explore a bit more about how these thoughts and feelings affect your daily life. For example, how do they impact your motivation, your relationships, or your ability to enjoy things? Would you be comfortable sharing more about that?
patient: Yeah, I think they really do affect me a lot. I find it hard to stay motivated, especially when I feel so overwhelmed and tired all the time. Sometimes I just want to give up on studying or even on my part-time job, but I know I can’t because I have to support myself. I don’t really enjoy things like I used to, and I feel distant from my friends and family because I don’t have the energy to connect with them. It’s like I’m just going through the motions, and nothing really feels fulfilling anymore.

clinician:
It sounds like these feelings are really taking a toll on your motivation and your ability to enjoy your life and relationships. Feeling distant from loved ones and losing interest in activities that once brought you joy can be very challenging. 

As we continue, I’d like to understand more about your thoughts and beliefs about yourself and your situation. For example, what do you tell yourself when you’re feeling overwhelmed or tired? Do you notice any particular patterns in your thinking?
patient: I guess I often tell myself that I’m not good enough or that I’m just not smart enough to handle all of this. I think I’m a failure because I can’t keep up with everything, and I worry that I’m disappointing my family and myself. Sometimes I think maybe I should just give up and stop trying so hard, but I also feel guilty about that. It’s like I’m stuck between feeling like I’m not enough and feeling like I have to keep going no matter what. It’s pretty exhausting to think like that all the time.

clinician:
It sounds like you’re caught in a difficult cycle of self-criticism and guilt, feeling like you’re not enough but also feeling compelled to keep pushing yourself. These kinds of thoughts can be very draining and can reinforce feelings of depression and exhaustion. 

When you notice these thoughts about not being enough or feeling like a failure, how do you usually respond to them? Do you find yourself believing them, or do you question them at all?
patient: Honestly, I tend to believe those thoughts most of the time. It’s hard not to, especially when I see myself struggling or falling behind. I think I just accept that I’m not good enough and that I’ll never be able to do everything I want to do. Sometimes I try to tell myself I should be kinder to myself, but it doesn’t really work. It’s like these negative thoughts just take over my mind, and I can’t seem to shake them off.

clinician:
It sounds like these negative thoughts about yourself are quite persistent and difficult to challenge, even when you try to be kinder to yourself. Recognizing that they take over your mind is an important insight. 

In our work together, we can explore ways to gently question and reframe these thoughts, so they don’t feel so overwhelming. We can also look at strategies to help you manage these feelings of guilt and self-criticism, and find some ways to build a more supportive inner dialogue. 

Before we move toward that, is there anything else about your experience or feelings that you think is important for me to understand?
patient: Yes, I think I also feel a lot of pressure to succeed because I’m the first in my family to go to college. I want to make my parents proud, but sometimes I worry that I’m not doing enough or that I’m letting them down. It’s like I carry this huge responsibility on my shoulders, and it’s hard to breathe sometimes. I don’t really talk about this with anyone either, because I don’t want to seem ungrateful or like I’m complaining. It just feels like I’m carrying so much weight all the time.

clinician:
Thank you for sharing that, Mei Lin. It’s clear that your role as the first in your family to attend college adds an extra layer of pressure and responsibility, which can be very heavy to carry. Feeling like you’re not doing enough or that you might disappoint your parents is understandable, especially given how much you want to make them proud. 

This sense of responsibility and the desire to meet expectations can be exhausting, especially when you’re already feeling overwhelmed. As we continue, we can explore ways to help you manage these feelings of pressure and find a balance that allows you to care for yourself while honoring your commitments. 

Would you like to share what you hope to achieve through our sessions or any specific goals you have in mind?
patient: Yes, I think I just want to feel less overwhelmed and more able to handle everything without feeling so exhausted all the time. I’d like to find ways to be kinder to myself and maybe talk about my feelings more openly, even if it’s hard. I also hope I can figure out how to manage the guilt and pressure I feel, so I don’t feel so weighed down. Mostly, I just want to feel a little more hopeful and less stuck in this cycle.

clinician:
Thank you for sharing your goals, Mei Lin. It’s very helpful to understand what you’re hoping to work toward—feeling less overwhelmed, being kinder to yourself, managing guilt and pressure, and cultivating hope. 

In our work together, we can develop practical strategies to help you achieve these goals, such as challenging negative thoughts, building self-compassion, and finding ways to connect more openly with others. 

Would you be interested in starting with some specific techniques to help you recognize and reframe unhelpful thoughts, or perhaps exploring ways to gradually share your feelings with trusted people?
patient: Yes, I think I’d like to start with learning how to recognize and challenge those negative thoughts. Sometimes I don’t even realize I’m thinking them until I feel really bad. I want to understand how to catch those thoughts early and maybe replace them with something more kind or realistic. I think that could help me feel a little better day-to-day.

clinician:
That’s a very good starting point, Mei Lin. Recognizing and challenging negative thoughts is a core part of CBT and can be very effective in reducing feelings of depression and self-criticism. 

To begin, we can work on developing some awareness of these thoughts as they happen. For example, when you notice yourself feeling overwhelmed or guilty, try to pause and ask yourself what specific thoughts are going through your mind at that moment. 

Once you identify a negative thought, we can look at ways to evaluate its accuracy and consider alternative, more balanced perspectives. Would you like to try a simple exercise now, where you share a recent negative thought you’ve had, and we can work through how to challenge it?
patient: Sure, I’d be willing to try that. I think one thought I often have is, “I’m not good enough,” especially when I see my grades or compare myself to others. It’s like this voice in my head that keeps saying I’ll never be enough no matter what I do. I guess I don’t really know how to challenge it, though.

clinician:
Thank you for sharing that, Mei Lin. Recognizing the thought “I’m not good enough” is an important first step. Now, let’s work together to evaluate this thought. 

Ask yourself: What evidence do I have that supports this thought? And what evidence do I have that contradicts it? 

For example, are there times when you’ve succeeded or received positive feedback? Or are there moments when you’ve managed challenges or learned new things? 

Would you like to try applying this to your thought now?
patient: Yeah, I guess I can try. Well, I have gotten good grades before, and my professors have told me I’m doing well sometimes. I also managed to finish my last project, even if it was stressful. But then I think about how I still feel like I’m falling behind or not doing enough, and I compare myself to classmates who seem to get everything done easily. So, I guess there’s some evidence that I am capable, but I still feel like I’m not enough.

clinician:
That’s a very thoughtful reflection, Mei Lin. You’ve identified some evidence that supports your capability, like good grades and completing projects, which is important to recognize. At the same time, you’re aware of the feelings of falling behind and comparing yourself to others, which can fuel the negative thought. 

A helpful way to reframe this thought might be to acknowledge both sides. For example, you could tell yourself, “I’ve achieved a lot and am capable, even if I sometimes feel like I’m not enough. It’s normal to have doubts, but they don’t define my worth.” 

Would you like to practice creating a more balanced or compassionate version of that thought?
patient: Yes, I think I’d like to try that. Maybe I can tell myself, “I’ve done well so far, and I’m capable, even if I feel overwhelmed sometimes. It’s okay to have doubts, but they don’t mean I’m not enough.” I guess that sounds a little kinder and more realistic.

clinician:
That’s a wonderful reframe, Mei Lin. It’s kinder, more balanced, and acknowledges your efforts and capabilities while also recognizing your feelings. Practicing this kind of self-talk can gradually help you feel more supported and less critical of yourself. 

Would you like to set a goal to practice this kind of thought-reframing during the week? Or perhaps identify other common negative thoughts you’d like to work on?
patient: Yes, I think I’d like to try practicing this kind of thinking more often. Maybe I can write down some of these balanced thoughts and remind myself when I start feeling overwhelmed or guilty. I’d also like to become more aware of other negative thoughts I have, so I can challenge them too. It feels a little scary, but I think it might help me feel a bit better.

clinician:
That’s a very proactive and thoughtful approach, Mei Lin. Writing down balanced thoughts and reminders can be a helpful way to reinforce positive self-talk. Becoming more aware of your negative thoughts is a key step, and it’s understandable that it feels a bit scary—change often does. 

As you practice, remember to be gentle with yourself and recognize that this is a process. Over time, it can help you develop a more compassionate and realistic view of yourself, which can reduce feelings of overwhelm and guilt. 

Would you like some tips on how to keep track of these thoughts or how to remind yourself to practice this during busy or stressful times?
patient: Yes, I’d appreciate that. Sometimes I forget to notice my thoughts until I’m already feeling really down, so any tips on how to stay aware would be helpful. Maybe some kind of reminder or a way to catch myself earlier would work. I want to try to be more mindful of my thinking, but I don’t really know how to do that consistently.

clinician:
That’s a very common challenge, Mei Lin, and it’s great that you’re interested in developing more mindfulness around your thoughts. Here are some strategies that might help you stay more aware and catch negative thoughts earlier:

1. **Set Regular Reminders:** You could use alarms or notifications on your phone at specific times during the day to pause and check in with your thoughts and feelings.

2. **Create a Thought-Check Routine:** Incorporate a brief mental or physical check-in, like taking a few deep breaths and asking yourself, “What am I thinking right now?” or “How am I feeling?” during moments of transition, such as between classes or before studying.

3. **Use a Thought Journal:** Keep a small notebook or digital document where you jot down negative thoughts as they occur. Over time, this can help you notice patterns and triggers.

4. **Practice Mindfulness Meditation:** Even a few minutes daily of mindfulness meditation can increase your overall awareness of your thoughts and feelings, making it easier to notice them in real time.

Would you like guidance on how to start a simple mindfulness practice, or help creating a personalized reminder system?
patient: Yes, I think starting with a simple mindfulness practice would be good. I’ve heard it can help me become more aware of my thoughts without judgment. Maybe I can try just a few minutes each day to sit quietly and focus on my breathing or sensations. I’d like to see if that helps me notice my thoughts earlier and feel a bit more in control.

clinician:
That’s an excellent idea, Mei Lin. Starting with just a few minutes each day focusing on your breath or bodily sensations is a gentle and effective way to build mindfulness. It can help you become more aware of your thoughts and feelings without judgment, which is a key part of managing them more effectively.

Would you like me to guide you through a simple mindfulness exercise now, or provide some tips on how to incorporate this into your daily routine?
patient: Yes, I’d like that. I think a little guidance would help me get started. Maybe you can walk me through a short exercise I can do on my own?

clinician:
Absolutely, Mei Lin. Let’s do a brief mindfulness exercise together that you can practice on your own. Find a comfortable seated position, with your back straight but relaxed. Close your eyes if you feel comfortable, or soften your gaze.

Now, take a slow, deep breath in through your nose, feeling the air fill your lungs. Hold it for a moment, then gently exhale through your mouth or nose. As you continue to breathe slowly and naturally, bring your attention to the sensation of your breath—notice the feeling of the air entering and leaving your body.

If your mind starts to wander to thoughts or feelings, gently acknowledge them without judgment, and then bring your focus back to your breath. You might silently say to yourself, “Inhale, exhale,” to help anchor your attention.

Try to do this for about 2-3 minutes, gradually increasing the time as you feel comfortable. The goal isn’t to clear your mind completely but to observe your experience with kindness and curiosity.

Would you like me to check in with you after you try this a few times, or help you develop a plan to incorporate it into your daily routine?
patient: Yes, I think I can try that on my own. It sounds manageable, and I like the idea of just focusing on my breath. I’ll give it a shot and see how it goes. Thank you for guiding me through it.

clinician:
You're very welcome, Mei Lin. I'm glad you feel comfortable trying this practice on your own. Remember, it's normal for your mind to wander—that's part of the process. With regular practice, it can become easier to notice your thoughts earlier and respond to them more kindly. 

If you find it helpful, we can check in next time about how this practice is going and explore any challenges or successes you experience. For now, take it at your own pace, and be gentle with yourself as you begin this new habit. 

See you next time!
